ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Question 6-7: The only field trip to the museum was very interesting and provided a different way of thinking about representation of nature. I hope there had been more field trips from this class.

Question 10. Prof. Doolittle has been incredibly generous. Her guidance has been key in designing a research project for my MESc that promises to be successful. Working with Prof. Doolittle I feel confident of the success of my two years at FES. Without her, I probably would have been lost.

In response to q. 2: I wish that more of the assignments had been more directly about preparing for writing the proposal. Writing the final proposal was of course helpful, but I feel that aside from the lit review, I was having to come up with most of it from scratch. It would have been great if we had had to write sections about methodology, etc, as homework assignments, so that we would have been able to get feedback on them.

Professor Doolittle was exceptional. She is clearly dedicated to the class and her students, as evidenced by the amount of time she put into structuring her lectures and providing feedback on assignments. She made herself frequently accessible for office hours as well.I learned a significant amount from the class and it proved extremely useful for coming up with a model research proposal for grant-writing purposes.Kendall, the TF, was also helpful, providing copious feedback on the proposal and other assignments. It was also great to have her insight as a person who has applied for and received grants, as well as carried out qualitative research.
This was a key course than helped me develop a research proposal at the end of the semester.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: writing proposal
The assignments for this class were very applicable. We applied what we were learning in readings and class lectures to our individual research.
Amity. She's great.

The assignments (e.g identity memos, comparative analysis of different articles, interviewing and coding) were very useful in helping me thinking and preparing for different aspects of doing research and fieldwork.
though she may not have been hired for very many hours, the TA (Kendall Barbery) was very accessible and ready to help

Out of class exercises, especially participant observation and interview transcription/coding, and conceptual diagrams.Writing a literature review.Final presentations - good to practice, get feedback, and learn what cool stuff everyone is working on!Amity - I appreciated your wise words on the fact that research is an evolving process. You just have to start, adapt and don't worry about getting it perfect on the first go round because that's nearly impossible.

The literature review was KEY. Through this assignment I both became well read in my area of interest, and learned how to build an argument upon current research. These two lessons are essential for my success at FES.
Final proposal.
General coverage of qualitative techniques, the progression through writing a research proposal.

I know that having written this proposal will prove to be very helpful in the future, as I apply for various types of funding. It was also good to solidify my research questions throughout the course.
The lectures were great, as were the thought-provoking assignments. I also enjoyed our discussions, which were always dynamic and enthusiastic.
The best aspect of this course were the peer reading groups where 3-4 students read each other's work and improve

I appreciate the different assignments that required us to actually go through each one of them in detail. I especially appreciate the participant observation, the interview and the interview coding. I realized there were more to each one of these exercises and had a new-found appreciation for them.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Students should have a good idea of what they want to research before taking this course. If you are unsure of your research goals, this class can be frustrating.
Many good suggestions have been discussed in class
This may not belong in this class, but it would be great to cover more quantitative techniques in the social sciences.

The guest speakers from the library, the IRB, and the survey guy all were weak presentations. I think I have a lot to learn about those subjects. The treatment in the class from these guests was too superficial to be useful.
Perhaps a little more time on the literature review would be helpful. I still feel fairly uncomfortable with this type of work.

There was a lot of survey of techniques--talking about them without really learning about them. I would like more exchange and dialogue between students-- this was a great way to learn and share experiences.

The homework and readings could be more relevant to the actual writing of the proposal. I found that after the first several weeks, the readings were not that relevant. I also wish that we would have had homework assignments that contributed more directly to our proposals (other than the lit review, which of course was very helpful).
Finding ways to better integrate learning data management...these lectures were the most difficult for me to incorporate into my own repertoire---my notes on these things are pretty scattered...
The time allocated for literature review was shorter than it should be. Students could be advised to start literature review starting from the first week.

I think that there should have been a more direct relationship between the assignments and the stage of the research that we did at the time of the assignments. Especially with the different topics and levels of skill and knowledge each of the students had, it will have been very valuable to see the development of our respective researches as we moved along the semester.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: more discussion and less peer review
Good
Course lecture was providing the key concepts and tools up on which our peer group discusses on and our proposal work. This was the most effective in that regard
My response regarding the possible improvement in the course is already mentioned in the preceding question's answer.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This class gives you the tools you need to conduct research over summer not only through qualitative methods but also through the different resources available to you at Yale (funding etc).
Helpful in deciding between MEM or MESc track.

As an MESc I took this class out of obligation. Still, it proved to be the most valuable class I took this semester. This is the class where I learned to be a grad student. I have been out of school for 8 years before coming back for my masters. I needed to have a place where I could learn HOW to be in school again, or fall behind very quickly. The skills I learned in research in this class have been useful in each of the other classes I took.
This course would be most helpful for MESc students or other students who have a formal research topic in mind.

This course is most useful for students wishing to do research over the summer, who already have SOME idea of what they might want to do. For these people, the progression is good, though more pointed feedback from the instructor would be helpful. It helped me think about issues I am interested in, but ultimately would have been better if I had had a research topic or area already picked out.
I will be conducting ethnographic research, both in the Master's and the potential PhD, so this course was indispensable.
See Question 14
This course is a research methods course. I exactly was necessary to build a research proposal for summer

i intend to conduct a sccial science research in the Philippines. As such I would like to be adept and clearly aware of the requirements for research of Yale University and the School. Thus, it was necessary for me to take the research course that would prepare me to conduct the research during the summer.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: assist my research
I wanted to learn more about qualitative research methods as well as receive feedback on my summer research ideas.
Requirement
To decide if I wanted to pursue MESc or MEM
See above. (question 17)

I wanted to learn more about qualitative methods for research-- as I have done some in the past--I would have liked to have developed a stronger grounding in this, so at least whether or not I had a full research proposal, at least I could have felt like i had developed some skills.
Because it is a requirement of the MESc degree.
It is a requirement.
To decide if I wanted to do research...I did not originally intend to when I came into the program.
Because it is a course that teaches how I should approach research work.
I feel that my skills and knowledge in conducting research needs improvement. Therefore, taking a course on research methods would be the most appropriate way to improve such skills and knowledge.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes!
Absolutely.
Yes.

Yes. Coming from a science background, it was quite eye opening to understand the research paradigms that researchers in different academic disciplines operate under (positivist, post-positivist, etc). It was also took away some important knowledge of true difficulties of interdisciplinary and mixed methods research, at least within academia.
Yes.
Yes, I have a must better sense of what qualitative research entails. I believe this course prepared me well for a formal research project that I hope to undertake this coming summer.
Not fully. I think I wasn't as clear on this as I thought at the beginning.

I feel like overall it could have been a bit better. I still feel like most of my final proposal was kind of vague, or at least that I didn't know what was expected of me for most of the sections. So I feel that it would have been great if we had spent more time in class going over proposals step by step...
Yes, but I may have wanted more time spent on methods.
It was a very helpful course
I have gained so much knowledge on research techniques and tools through this course. It was beyond my expectation
Yes. I truly feel more comfortable in conducting the research and hopefully what I've gained would be sufficient to let me do the research during the summer.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: My partners showed little attention or care to the group work. This was disappointing.
peer review

The advantages of the group was that you received feedback from your peers on your work. The disadvantage was that if the people in your group didn't attend class, their ability to support your work was limited (and it was challenging to add yourself to another group that hadn't followed your trajectory of work).
It was great to have a consistent group of people peer-editing your work. It's very enlightening.

Peer review is an incredibly valuable process. It may have been more useful to group students with similar research projects as opposed to different research projects (although I can't really decide).

We did only a little group work, but I found it valuable. We had small groups to peer review each other's work. My peers offered great criticism. Because of that exercise I plan to initiate a peer review group in the SIG I am involved in.
Work groups were great, but would have liked to see more sharing amongst groups and hearing more about what everyone in the class was doing.
The peer review stuff was really helpful! I got some really good feedback from my group, which helped shape my proposal a lot.
It was generative to get feedback and talk things over with peers, but because our interests were so disparate,I ended up forming separate peer groups anyway.

Great to get exposure to what classmates were working on and to be able to witness/support each other through our own processes...it re-affirmed the fluid nature of doing this work. It was also great to meet peers and have the opportunity to get to know each other a bit better and to start recognizing we as scholars can support each other in our work.
It was rewarding to learn from other students and noble idea to share views

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Know what you want to research (or a pretty good idea) before you attend this class, otherwise, it will be very challenging for you (and perhaps not that useful).
Very good introduction to the broad range of things you could consider for your research.
You get out of this course what you put into it. It is obviously more suited towards self-motivated students with a research topic in mind.

The more you put in, the more you get out. Start early on the lit. review. Make sure to read literature relevant to your subject every week (even before the lit. review is due) or you will have a huge push when the lit. review is due.
Come into the class with a particular subject or topic you want to specifically research. You need to "hit the ground running."
Don't take this to develop skills--take this to work your way through the topic you already know you are interested in.

If you're going to take this, it's probably because you have to. Overall, it is helpful to have a course where the entire goal is to write a proposal... I feel that I'll end up using it in the future.
It's a great course, so as long as you do it justice -- put in the time to think about the assignments and take advantage of the office hours Amity offers, as well as the TF's knowhow.
You get out of it what you put into it.
For anyone who intends to conduct a research, this provides the tools and techniques for a social research. This is a must to take course.

I think it would be very valuable for a student who intended to take this course to be prepared with the research that he or she plans to do or conduct. Absent a significant investment and involvement in the research you intend to undertake, taking the research method will prove to be more complicated than it should be.Also, a ready research helps to understand the different assignments more directly given that the research is a ready subject where the different assignments might help improve the research.
